'The Bay Was Packed With Ships'
How did a 'divine wind' save Japan from Mon=
golian invaders 700 years

By Hideko Takayama
Newsweek

Aug. 16 issue =
- Kublai Khan was a conqueror of boundless appetite. 
When Japan refused to=
 obey and pay tribute to the Mongolian ruler, he 
was outraged. Twice durin=
g the 13th century he sent massive fleets to 
invade Japan, possibly trying=
 to seize its storied gold. Each time,

epelled not by the Japanese

 of the invaders and

ms kamikaze, or

e blow? How

ps? And

the

cts uncovered in an expedition that ended last week tell more

ttles that took place off the coast of the tiny island of

 mouth of Imari Bay, 1,000 kilometers southwest of

Digging up the =

t task, to say the least. Excavations that

y Kenzo Hayashida, archeologist and

ciety for Underwater

Hayashida and his crew fell short o=

t=
he hundreds of wooden pieces the team turned up, as well as those

lier expeditions, Hayashida thinks that some of the ships of

 fleet could have been 40 meters, and made in Chinese or

To=
day the island (population: 2,800) is covered with lush green pine 
and swe=
et-acorn trees, and the fishermen pride themselves on their

. It's hard to imagine that this bucolic island was the

 biggest and most devastating sea battles in

e 40,000 soldiers aboard 900 wooden

 and killed virtually 
Takashima's entire population. For some unknown reas=

 its way

ved

00 ships and 100,000 soldiers are believed to have vanished under

Shinji Takano, archeologist with the Nagasaki Prefectural Board of

tion, thinks that the fleet gathered in the bay to let the

 study of a Southern Sung dynasty military ship

may have been similar in design to the

of nearly 200kmh would have been

s that a mega typhoon wind

packed with their

 stay

ar his team has
